trans-unit.source: How to create a Virtual Network (VNet)
trans-unit.target: How to create a Virtual Network (VNet)

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create a virtual network (VNet)
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create a virtual network (VNet)

trans-unit.source: When you create a VNet, your services and VMs within the VNet can communicate securely with each other without having to go out through the Internet.
trans-unit.target: When you create a VNet, your services and VMs within the VNet can communicate securely with each other without having to go out through the Internet.

trans-unit.source: Creating an Azure VNet is a relatively fast and easy process if the VNet isn’t intended to be connected to other VNets or to your on-premises network, since you will not need to acquire and configure a VPN device, or coordinate the IP addresses you choose with other VNets or the local network.
trans-unit.target: Creating an Azure VNet is a relatively fast and easy process if the VNet isn’t intended to be connected to other VNets or to your on-premises network, since you will not need to acquire and configure a VPN device, or coordinate the IP addresses you choose with other VNets or the local network.

trans-unit.source: Don’t use this procedure to create a VNet that will later be connected other VNets or your on-premises network.
trans-unit.target: Don’t use this procedure to create a VNet that will later be connected other VNets or your on-premises network.

trans-unit.source: If you want to create a secure cross-premises or hybrid connection, see <linkText>About Virtual Network Secure Cross-Premises Connectivity</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to create a secure cross-premises or hybrid connection, see <linkText>About Virtual Network Secure Cross-Premises Connectivity</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to create a VNet that connects to another VNet, see <linkText>Configure a VNet to VNet Connection</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to create a VNet that connects to another VNet, see <linkText>Configure a VNet to VNet Connection</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Log in to the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: In the lower left-hand corner of the screen, click New.
trans-unit.target: In the lower left-hand corner of the screen, click New.

trans-unit.source: In the navigation pane, click Network Services, and then click Virtual Network.
trans-unit.target: In the navigation pane, click Network Services, and then click Virtual Network.

trans-unit.source: Click Custom Create to begin the configuration wizard.
trans-unit.target: Click Custom Create to begin the configuration wizard.

trans-unit.source: On the Virtual Network Details page, enter the information below:
trans-unit.target: On the Virtual Network Details page, enter the information below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Virtual Network Details</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Virtual Network Details</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Name - Name your VNet.
trans-unit.target: Name - Name your VNet.

trans-unit.source: For example, we created the name EastUSVNet.
trans-unit.target: For example, we created the name EastUSVNet.

trans-unit.source: You can create whatever name you’d like.
trans-unit.target: You can create whatever name you’d like.

trans-unit.source: You will use this VNet name when you deploy your VMs and services, so it’s best not to make the name too complicated.
trans-unit.target: You will use this VNet name when you deploy your VMs and services, so it’s best not to make the name too complicated.

trans-unit.source: Location – Select the location (region) from the drop-down.
trans-unit.target: Location – Select the location (region) from the drop-down.

trans-unit.source: The location is directly related to the physical location where you want your resources (VMs) to reside when you deploy them to this VNet.
trans-unit.target: The location is directly related to the physical location where you want your resources (VMs) to reside when you deploy them to this VNet.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you want your VMs to be physically located in East US, select that location region.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you want your VMs to be physically located in East US, select that location region.

trans-unit.source: You can’t change the region associated with your VNet after you create it.
trans-unit.target: You can’t change the region associated with your VNet after you create it.

trans-unit.source: On the DNS Servers and VPN Connectivity page, don’t make any changes.
trans-unit.target: On the DNS Servers and VPN Connectivity page, don’t make any changes.

trans-unit.source: Just move forward to the next page by clicking the arrow.
trans-unit.target: Just move forward to the next page by clicking the arrow.

trans-unit.source: By default, Azure provides basic name resolution for your VNet.
trans-unit.target: By default, Azure provides basic name resolution for your VNet.

trans-unit.source: It’s possible that your name resolution requirements are more complex than can be handled by the basic Azure name resolution.
trans-unit.target: It’s possible that your name resolution requirements are more complex than can be handled by the basic Azure name resolution.

trans-unit.source: In that case, you may later want to add a virtual machine running DNS to your VNet.
trans-unit.target: In that case, you may later want to add a virtual machine running DNS to your VNet.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Azure name resolution and DNS, see <linkText>Name Resolution (DNS)</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure name resolution and DNS, see <linkText>Name Resolution (DNS)</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The Virtual Network Address Spaces page is where you enter the address space that you want to use for this VNet.
trans-unit.target: The Virtual Network Address Spaces page is where you enter the address space that you want to use for this VNet.

trans-unit.source: Unless you require a certain internal IP address range for your VMs or you want to create a specific subnet for VMs that will receive a static DIP, you don’t need to make any changes on this page.
trans-unit.target: Unless you require a certain internal IP address range for your VMs or you want to create a specific subnet for VMs that will receive a static DIP, you don’t need to make any changes on this page.

trans-unit.source: If you do want to create multiple subnets, you can do so on this page by clicking add subnet.
trans-unit.target: If you do want to create multiple subnets, you can do so on this page by clicking add subnet.

trans-unit.source: Additional Information:
trans-unit.target: Additional Information:

trans-unit.source: The ranges on this page contain the dynamic internal IP addresses (DIPs) that your VMs will receive when you deploy them to this VNet.
trans-unit.target: The ranges on this page contain the dynamic internal IP addresses (DIPs) that your VMs will receive when you deploy them to this VNet.

trans-unit.source: These IP addresses are for communicating within the VNet only.
trans-unit.target: These IP addresses are for communicating within the VNet only.

trans-unit.source: They are not IP addresses for internet endpoints.
trans-unit.target: They are not IP addresses for internet endpoints.

trans-unit.source: Because you aren’t going to connect this private VNet to your on-premises network by using a cross-premises VPN configuration, you won’t need to coordinate these settings with your existing on-premises network IP address ranges.
trans-unit.target: Because you aren’t going to connect this private VNet to your on-premises network by using a cross-premises VPN configuration, you won’t need to coordinate these settings with your existing on-premises network IP address ranges.

trans-unit.source: If you think you may want to create a cross-premises configuration later, you’ll need to coordinate the address spaces now with the ranges that already exist on your local site to avoid routing issues.
trans-unit.target: If you think you may want to create a cross-premises configuration later, you’ll need to coordinate the address spaces now with the ranges that already exist on your local site to avoid routing issues.

trans-unit.source: Changing the ranges later can be somewhat complicated, especially if you have overlapping address ranges.
trans-unit.target: Changing the ranges later can be somewhat complicated, especially if you have overlapping address ranges.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Address Space</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Address Space</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click the checkmark on the lower right of the Virtual Network Address Spaces page and your VNet will be created.
trans-unit.target: Click the checkmark on the lower right of the Virtual Network Address Spaces page and your VNet will be created.

trans-unit.source: When your VNet has been created, you will see Created listed under Status on the networks page in the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: When your VNet has been created, you will see Created listed under Status on the networks page in the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Once your VNet has been created, you can create VMs and PaaS instances within the VNet.
trans-unit.target: Once your VNet has been created, you can create VMs and PaaS instances within the VNet.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to select From Gallery when creating a new VM in order to have the option of selecting your VNet.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to select From Gallery when creating a new VM in order to have the option of selecting your VNet.

trans-unit.source: Note that if you have already existing VMs and PaaS instances deployed, they cannot simply be moved to your new VNet.
trans-unit.target: Note that if you have already existing VMs and PaaS instances deployed, they cannot simply be moved to your new VNet.

trans-unit.source: This is because the network configuration settings that they’ll need are added during deployment.
trans-unit.target: This is because the network configuration settings that they’ll need are added during deployment.

trans-unit.source: After you create your VNet, you can add new VMs to it.
trans-unit.target: After you create your VNet, you can add new VMs to it.

trans-unit.source: It’s important to create the VNet first, then deploy the VM.
trans-unit.target: It’s important to create the VNet first, then deploy the VM.

trans-unit.source: After a VM has been deployed, you can’t move it to a VNet without redeploying it.
trans-unit.target: After a VM has been deployed, you can’t move it to a VNet without redeploying it.

trans-unit.source: If you use the Management Portal to create your VMs, the interface to deploy your VM to a VNet is only available when you select New/ Compute/ Virtual Machine/ From Gallery.
trans-unit.target: If you use the Management Portal to create your VMs, the interface to deploy your VM to a VNet is only available when you select New/ Compute/ Virtual Machine/ From Gallery.

trans-unit.source: When you go through the wizard to create your VM, on the Virtual machine configuration page, you’ll see Region/Affinity Group/Virtual Network.
trans-unit.target: When you go through the wizard to create your VM, on the Virtual machine configuration page, you’ll see Region/Affinity Group/Virtual Network.

trans-unit.source: From the drop-down list, select the already-created VNet.
trans-unit.target: From the drop-down list, select the already-created VNet.

trans-unit.source: For more information about creating virtual machines, see <linkText>Azure virtual machines</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about creating virtual machines, see <linkText>Azure virtual machines</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>How to manage Virtual Network (VNet) Properties</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>How to manage Virtual Network (VNet) Properties</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>How to manage DNS servers used by a virtual network (VNet)</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>How to use public IP addresses in a virtual network</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>How to delete a Virtual Network (VNet)</linkText><title></title>
